title: Lactose Intolerance: The One Big Mistake and How To Fix It

content: As a dietitian in gastroenterology, lactose intolerance is likely the most frequent condition I encounter. It’s a prevalent issue, considering that lactase deficiency -- the enzyme responsible for breaking down lactose -- is estimated to affect nearly 70% of the global population.

Despite its commonality, confusion about lactase deficiency and its dietary consequences is widespread. Yet there is one major misconception I observe: the idea that you must swear off dairy for good.

In truth, eliminating dairy is not a primary defense, except in cases of milk allergy. Dairy can remain a part of your diet (unless you’ve happily moved on to plant-based alternatives). Managing it successfully just takes a bit of awareness and strategy.

Did you know that you can poorly digest lactose and still feel normal? Lactose malabsorption occurs when you don't produce enough lactase enzyme to digest lactose, but you may not notice symptoms. Lactose intolerance, however, occurs when lactose malabsorption leads to digestive upset, such as gas, bloating, or diarrhea, typically 2-8 hours later. If you've been diagnosed with lactase deficiency but don't notice any dairy aftermath, enjoy it freely. If you’re intolerant, there are practical solutions available.

sections.heading: Solution No. 1: Choose Naturally Lactose-Free Dairy
content: Butter. Cheddar cheese. Parmesan. These are just a few of the many naturally lactose-free foods you can enjoy despite lactose intolerance. Moreover, dairy with low lactose levels, like Greek yogurt and heavy cream, also tend to be well-tolerated in moderation. If a dairy product has no sugar or fruit added, the “total sugars” on the nutrition label indicates the lactose content. You may notice that some of your favorite dairy products are still suitable.
Solution No. 2: Choose Commercially Available Lactose-Free Dairy

With so many lactose intolerant shoppers, food companies now offer lactose-free versions of most dairy products. During manufacturing, the lactase enzyme gets added to milk to “pre-digest” the lactose beforehand. The result is lactose-free dairy, such as yogurt and ice cream, that are generally identical in taste and texture to regular milk products.
Solution No. 3: Use a Lactase Enzyme Supplement, Carefully

Solution No. 3: Use a Lactase Enzyme Supplement, Carefully

content: Over-the-counter lactase enzyme supplements conveniently prevent symptoms of lactose intolerance. However, certain conditions must be met for their effectiveness. If previous attempts with lactase were unsuccessful, consider these steps for better results:

sections.heading: Ensure adequate dosage.
content: Many products may not contain enough lactase (at least 9,000 units) to cover a lactose-rich meal, while others require taking several capsules to achieve a full dose. Check to make sure you take enough! The more lactose you consume, the more enzymes you need to process it. Severe lactose intolerance may call for extra supplementation.

Take with the first bite. Lactase must interact with the food in your stomach to work. Taking it too early or too late can be ineffective. Luckily, you don’t need to take lactase with all dairy foods, just those that are lactose-rich. This applies to meals, snacks, and desserts.
Re-dose for longer meals . Since enzymes have a short active duration, additional doses are recommended if your meal extends past 30-45 minutes.

Lactose intolerance isn’t the same for everyone. Your intolerance may be severe or very mild. It’s possible that small or even moderate amounts of lactose don’t cause symptoms for you. Before eliminating lactose, consider gradually experimenting with portion sizes to see what you can handle.

sections.heading: The Bottom Line
content: If you have lactose intolerance, dairy isn’t necessarily your enemy. Choose from naturally low or lactose-free dairy products, buy manufactured lactose-free dairy, supplement with a lactase enzyme, or try different portions. You may use a combination of these methods to live your best dairy life.
